passages.text:
The African moralist has always regarded smoking as an indication of moral degradation.

A number of people have accepted the moralist idea on smoking while a good many people have remained indifferent to the moralist view and have continued to smoke. The same argument has been applied to the consumption of alcohol. The African moralist, basing his judgement on the behaviour of a few alcoholics, tend to regard the habit of taking alcohol as a sign of wretchedness. The moralist holds the view that anybody who forms the habit of consuming alcohol will never do well in life. While this may be true in respect of a few people in the society, the fear of the moralist has not been justified.

However, the economist is primarily interested in the habit of smoking and the consumption of alcohol in so far as they give satisfaction to smokers and drinkers and so generate supply of and demand for tobacco and alcohol.

Some moral principles associated with religion tend to lead on to economic problems. Followers of certain religions are expected not to consume pork, take alcohol or smoke tobacco. Devotees of some religious groups, on the other hand, can eat pork while others are expected to abstain from alcohol and smoking.

Strict observance of these moral rules could cripple the breweries, the cigarette factories and some businesses; however, there seems to be a growing number of alcohol consumers and cigarette smokers—a development which should be of interest to the economist.

Adapted from Peter Scott's article in Sunday Times.

When man evolved a conscience, his basic relationship with the other animals began to change. Until then, they were broadly divided into those which ate him when they got the chance, those which he ate when he got the chance, and a third group which competed with him for food, or was otherwise a nuisance to him in the business of keeping alive.

In the primitive situation, man was, therefore, basically against nature but, as the battle was progressively won, conscience crept in; the awareness of responsibility, and a failure to meet it, produced feelings of guilt.

Those who live in cities and need no longer do battle against nature are nowadays most actively for nature. At this time, something like a thousand kinds of animals (vertebrate animals) can be said to be in danger of extinction. A few of them have been reduced to this precarious position by extensive killing but the majority are disappearing only as fast as the particular kind of country they need for existence is itself disappearing and all the hands of man, as often as not by mistake.

There are three species of turtles whose future survival is menaced by the demand for turtle soup, which would hardly justify the extermination of a giant reptile whose family has existed for 200 million years.

Leopards are in jeopardy because of the fashion for their skins. As they get rarer, the prices rise and, as leopard skin become more expensive, the demand increases. No species can long survive the price of N60,000 which a half-grown baby leopard now carries on its skin.

And crocodiles, the longest surviving reptiles, are now dwindling alarmingly as a result of the fashion in crocodile skin for ladies' handbags and men's shoes. The human population explosion spreads mankind across the land surfaces of the earth at an alarming rate. There will be twice as many of us before most of us are dead. Does this mean no room for wild animals? Of course not.

Adapted from Peter Scott's article in Sunday Times.

questions.question: The view expressed by the writer in the last paragraph is that

options.text: the number of alcoholics and smoker is certainly increasing
more people appear to take to drinking and smoking
sales of alcohol and tobacco products have improved tremendously
more people now abstain from drinking and smoking

questions.explanation: The passage states, 'there seems to be a growing number of alcohol consumers and cigarette smokers,' which directly supports option B. The text describes a trend of increasing consumption, not a decline (D), nor does it mention sales figures (C) or a specific increase in alcoholics (A).

questions.question: It can be concluded from the passage that morality, religion and economy are
questions.explanation: The passage shows a connection: moral/religious rules against alcohol/smoking can 'cripple' breweries and factories, indicating an economic impact. However, the text also notes the 'fear of the moralist has not been justified' and that economists focus on satisfaction and demand, suggesting the link is present but not absolute or 'clearly' defined. Thus, 'somewhat interconnected' is the most accurate conclusion.

questions.question: According to the passage, the moralist idea is that

options.text: the smoking of cigarettes is bad and unacceptable
it is typically African not to smoke cigarettes
people should accept a point of view only when they are convinced
smoking is not good but a little alcohol may be permitted

questions.explanation: The passage opens by stating, 'The African moralist has always regarded smoking as an indication of moral degradation.' This directly equates smoking with moral failing, making it 'bad and unacceptable.' The other options misrepresent the text: the passage doesn't claim non-smoking is 'typically African' (B), doesn't discuss acceptance criteria (C), and explicitly links alcohol to 'wretchedness' (D), not permissibility.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true according to the passage?

options.text: total abstinence from drinking and smoking is a religious obligation
smoking and drinking may have positive effects on the economy
every one ignores the moralist view on drinking and smoking
people who drink or smoke surely die of cancer

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states, 'the economist is primarily interested...in so far as they give satisfaction...and so generate supply of and demand for tobacco and alcohol.' This implies that these activities drive economic activity, which is a positive effect. Option A is too absolute ('total abstinence'), C is contradicted by the text ('a number of people have accepted the moralist idea'), and D is a medical claim not made in the passage.

questions.question: The positions maintained by the moralist and the economist can be described as being
questions.explanation: The moralist sees smoking/alcohol as 'moral degradation' and 'wretchedness,' while the economist sees them as sources of 'satisfaction' that 'generate supply and demand.' Their perspectives are fundamentally opposed—one is ethical, the other is utilitarian/economic. Therefore, their positions are 'at variance' (in disagreement).

questions.question: The sentence 'There will be twice as many of us before most of us are dead' means

options.text: some increase in human and animal population growth rates
mankind is fast spreading across the earth
the population growth rate will double before our death
many of us will die as a result of population explosion

questions.explanation: The phrase is a direct statement about human population numbers doubling within the lifespan of the current generation. It is a projection of growth, not a comment on spread (B), animal populations (A), or a prediction of mass death (D). The literal meaning is that the population will double before the current generation dies, making C the correct interpretation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true according to the passage?

options.text: man kills animal only when he can afford to do so.
man eats all categories of animals
man cannot spare those animals that eat his kind
man poses the greatest threat to nature

questions.explanation: The passage argues that while man once battled nature, he now 'is most actively for nature,' yet the primary cause of animal extinction is 'the particular kind of country they need for existence is itself disappearing and all the hands of man.' This places the blame for environmental damage squarely on human activity, making D the true statement. The other options are either unsupported (A, B) or contradict the text (C, which suggests a natural predator-prey dynamic, whereas the passage focuses on human-caused habitat loss).

questions.question: The basic causes of the elimination of certain animals from the earth include

options.text: a deliberate battle against nature and the quest for leopard skin
man's decision to live in cities and the development of large farm lands
man's penchant for meat and the sale of animals for meat and hides
extensive killing of animals and the fast disappearances of their favourable habitats

questions.explanation: The passage states that animals are disappearing due to 'extensive killing' and because 'the particular kind of country they need for existence is itself disappearing.' This directly matches option D. While A, B, and C are mentioned as contributing factors (e.g., killing for skins, living in cities leading to habitat loss), D provides the most comprehensive and direct summary of the two main causes cited in the text.

questions.question: The expression 'when man evolved a conscience' means when

options.text: man developed an awareness of right and wrong

questions.explanation: The passage immediately follows this phrase with 'the awareness of responsibility, and a failure to meet it, produced feelings of guilt.' Guilt and responsibility are hallmarks of a moral conscience, which is an awareness of right and wrong. The text does not link conscience to intellect (A), critical thinking (B), or mere habit acquisition (D).

questions.question: From the passage, the attitude of the writer can be described as
questions.explanation: The passage details the dire state of wildlife, mentioning 'danger of extinction,' 'dwindling alarmingly,' and 'human population explosion' causing habitat loss. The tone is one of warning and concern, highlighting negative trends without offering much hope for reversal. This aligns with a 'pessimistic' attitude. The writer is clearly not indifferent (A), partial (B), or optimistic (C).

questions.question: A prepared speech is not easy to deliver, especially if it is not written by the presenter .... 11 ....
questions.explanation: The context is about delivering a speech that has been 'written out word for word.' A 'manuscript' is a written document, specifically one that is ready for publication or performance. It fits perfectly. 'Quantum' is irrelevant, 'document' is too general, and 'free' makes no sense in this context.

questions.question: delivery is one in which the speech has been written out word for word and is read to - 12 -
questions.explanation: The most general and appropriate term for a group of people listening to a speech is 'an audience.' While a 'congregation' (B) or 'gathering' (C) might apply in specific contexts, 'audience' is the standard term used in public speaking. 'Conference' (D) refers to the event, not the listeners.

The delivery style described—reading a pre-written speech—is characteristic of formal occasions where precision is key. 'Impromptu' (B) is the opposite. 'Genuine' (A) and 'guaranteed' (C) are not relevant descriptors for the type of occasion.

questions.question: This kind of delivery is usually reserved for every --- 13 --- (a) genuine (b) impromptu (c) guaranteed (d) formal --- occasions when exact wording is - --- 14 --- (a) reportive (b) conclusive (c) critical --- such as the State of the Union Address or speeches before the United Nations General --- 15 --- (a) assembly (b) organisation (c) negotiation.

questions.question: This kind of delivery is usually reserved for every --- 13 --- (a) genuine (b) impromptu (c) guaranteed (d) formal --- occasions when exact wording is - --- 14 --- (a) reportive (b) conclusive (c) critical --- such as the State of the Union Address or speeches before the United Nations General --- 15 --- (a) assembly (b) organisation (c) negotiation.

questions.question: The primary advantage is that speech may be highly --- 16 --- (a) advanced (b) analogue (c) discreet (d) polished in terms of word choice, turns of phrase and development of ideas. The main advantage is that this type of delivery is difficult to do well.
questions.explanation: The passage describes the advantage as being able to refine 'word choice, turns of phrase and development of ideas.' This process results in a 'polished' speech—smooth, refined, and perfected. 'Advanced' (A) is too vague, 'analogue' (B) is irrelevant, and 'discreet' (C) means careful or unobtrusive, which doesn't fit the context of a public speech.

questions.question: According to the Novel, Efua was in Forcados High School because

options.text: her stepfather was a board member
the school needed her mother's support
of aunt Muni's gift to the school

questions.explanation: In the novel, Efua's admission is linked to her aunt, Muni, who made a significant financial contribution to the school. This is a key plot point explaining her presence at Forcados. The other options are not supported by the text.

questions.question: According to the Novel, who intimated Efua that there was a clash between area boys?
questions.explanation: Mr. Mallum, the principal, is the one who informs Efua about the potential violence involving the area boys. This occurs during a tense moment in the story, establishing his role as an authority figure concerned with student safety. The other teachers are not depicted as delivering this specific warning.

questions.question: The speculation amongst the students of Forcados High School gas that Jimi was dating
questions.explanation: Throughout the novel, there is widespread gossip among students that Jimi and Efua are romantically involved. This speculation is a recurring theme, driving much of the interpersonal drama. The other girls are not subjects of this particular rumor.

questions.question: The best thing that happened to Efua at the end of the term was

options.text: her participation in the Christmas concert
her exclusion from Miss Novi's charity group
the principal's open commendation of her result

questions.explanation: Efua's academic success is a major triumph for her, especially after facing social and institutional challenges. The principal's public praise is a powerful validation of her hard work and intelligence, making it the 'best thing' that happened to her. The other events are either neutral or negative.

questions.question: When did a boy faint at Forcados High School?
questions.explanation: The fainting incident occurs during the Mid-term dinner, a significant social event in the novel. This moment adds to the drama and tension surrounding the characters' interactions. The other events are not associated with this specific incident.

questions.question: Mr Mallum, the principal, was a symbol of
questions.explanation: Mr. Mallum is portrayed as a successful and respected figure, embodying the ideals of education and discipline. He represents what students aspire to achieve. His character is not associated with freedom (A), envy (B), or condemnation (C).

questions.question: Ansa decided not to like Efua because he
questions.explanation: Ansa perceives Efua as aloof and superior, which he interprets as snobbishness. This perception fuels his dislike for her. The other options do not accurately reflect his motivations as presented in the novel.

questions.question: In the novel, Ansa looked around glumly when Jimi was engrossed in laughter and chatter because he was

options.text: distracted by a b playing on the field
given twelve strokes of the cane by the principal

questions.explanation: Ansa feels jealous and left out when Jimi is socializing with others, particularly Efua. His glum expression stems from feeling neglected by his friend. The other options are not supported by the narrative context.

questions.question: Which of the following statements captures Ansa's thought about Jimi?

options.text: He thought Jimi was a lucky boy
He was going to break his friendship with Jimi
He thought Jimi cut corners to succeed
He was envious of Jimi's achievement

questions.explanation: Ansa's character is marked by envy towards Jimi, who is academically brilliant and socially popular. Ansa's thoughts often revolve around his resentment of Jimi's success. The other options do not capture the core of his internal conflict.

questions.question: Jimi was still trembling when he got home from the bar because

options.text: he ran into a team of policemen
Wole's friend wanted to beat him
he saw an accident on the way

questions.explanation: Jimi's trembling is a physical reaction to the stress of evading the police after the incident at the bar. The encounter with law enforcement is a pivotal and frightening moment for him. The other options are not part of the narrative.

questions.question: After listening to Jimi's explanation on the stolen laboratory equipments, Mr Mallum decided to

options.text: get in touch with Jimi's relations
punish Jimi for the wrong doings
put an end to the matter
contact the police for Jimi's release

questions.explanation: Mr. Mallum, demonstrating understanding and a desire to protect the school's reputation, chooses to resolve the issue internally rather than escalate it. He decides to 'put an end to the matter,' showing leniency. The other actions are not taken by him.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Mr Mallum?

options.text: He was a small, wiry man with odd accent
He was a tall, wiry man with good diction
He was crude, rash and impatient
He was a fat, tall man with wimpyish behaviour

questions.explanation: The novel describes Mr. Mallum as having a commanding presence, being tall and wiry, with clear and articulate speech. This description matches option B. The other options contradict the textual portrayal of his character.

questions.question: How did Nene feel when she saw Efua's painting by Ansa?
questions.explanation: Nene is taken aback by the quality and subject of the painting, which reveals a hidden talent and perspective from Efua. Her reaction is one of surprise, not delight or timidity. The text does not suggest she became friendly as a direct result.

questions.question: One of the things Ansa observed about his fellow students when they resumed for the new term was that some of them

options.text: wore their ties in odd knots
were eager to go back home

questions.explanation: Ansa notices the physical toll the holidays have taken on some students, describing them as looking 'sickly and malnourished.' This observation highlights the socioeconomic disparities among the student body. The other options are not mentioned in the text.

questions.question: Efua was not in the good book of teachers at Forcados High School because

options.text: her admission into the senior class was unusual
she was expelled from her previous school
the students of the school did not like her
she bribed the principal before she was admitted

questions.explanation: Efua's past, including her expulsion from a previous school, follows her to Forcados and contributes to the teachers' initial prejudice against her. This background is a key reason for their disapproval. The other reasons are not cited as primary causes.

questions.question: These questions are based on A. H. Mohammed's "The First Days at Forcados High School"
questions.explanation: This is a meta-question indicating the start of the section based on the novel. The first question in this section is Q21, making A the correct answer to identify the beginning of the set.

questions.question: Ramatu expressed her feelings in no uncertain terms

options.text: she expressed it feebly and sickly
she expresses it quietly and cautiously
she expressed it secretly and courageously
she expressed it clearly and strongly

questions.explanation: The idiom 'in no uncertain terms' means to express something in a very clear, direct, and forceful manner. Option D is the only one that accurately captures this meaning. The other options describe weakness, secrecy, or caution, which are the opposite of the idiom's intent.

questions.question: Usman needs to get his act together if he wants to pass the examination

options.text: he needs to put on his stage costume
he needs to be fast when writing the examination
he needs to put all points down in the examination

questions.explanation: The idiom 'get his act together' means to organize oneself, become more efficient, or start behaving responsibly. In the context of an exam, it implies getting organized and focused. The other options are literal misinterpretations of the idiom.

questions.question: As the drama unfolded, Olatinuke was advised to keep her shirt on

options.text: she was advised to stay calm
she was advised to commit herself
she was advised to join the club
she was advised to wear her shirt

questions.explanation: The idiom 'keep your shirt on' is a colloquial way of telling someone to remain calm or not to get angry. The advice is for Olatinuke to manage her emotions during the unfolding drama. The other options are literal and do not fit the idiomatic usage.

questions.question: The team's poor performance at the tournament plunged the depths of horror.

options.text: the team's performance took them to the next round
the team's performance was enjoyed by all
the team's performance was full of disappointment

questions.explanation: The phrase 'plunged the depths of horror' is hyperbolic, emphasizing extreme negativity. It means the performance was disastrous and deeply disappointing. The other options suggest positive outcomes, which directly contradict the phrase's meaning.

questions.question: He is a clinging child

options.text: He likes to cling with his sister
He is a handsome young man

questions.explanation: Describing a child as 'clinging' means they are overly dependent and seek constant attention or physical closeness, which is a form of possessiveness. It does not imply bullying (A), a specific relationship with a sister (B), or physical appearance (D).

questions.question: You need to brush up on your Spanish

options.text: you need a brush from Spain
you need to study the history of Spain
you need to learn to play with a Spaniard
you need to improve your skills.

questions.explanation: The idiom 'brush up on' means to review or refresh one's knowledge or skills in a particular area. Therefore, 'brush up on your Spanish' means to improve or revise your Spanish language skills. The other options are literal and nonsensical interpretations.

questions.question: Tolu and Chinedu live in each other's pockets

options.text: They are very close to each other

questions.explanation: The idiom 'live in each other's pockets' means to spend a lot of time together, often to the point of being inseparable. It signifies a very close relationship. The other options misinterpret the idiom literally or assign an opposite meaning.

questions.question: Zinana's examination result was not unfavourable

options.text: Her result could not earn her admission
She was successful in the examination
She was not successful in the examination

questions.explanation: The phrase 'not unfavourable' is a double negative, meaning 'favourable' or 'good.' Therefore, Zinana's result was good, indicating she was successful. The other options suggest failure or inadequacy, which contradicts the statement.

questions.question: can't wait to become a mother. 'the new bride declared

options.text: she sees motherhood as a burden
she will be patient as a mother
She is not keen on becoming a mother

questions.explanation: The phrase 'can't wait' expresses eagerness and excitement. The bride's declaration indicates she is looking forward to motherhood with anticipation. The other options suggest reluctance, patience, or disinterest, which are contrary to the sentiment expressed.

questions.question: The relationship between the couple has been frosty
questions.explanation: The word 'frosty' in this context means cold, unfriendly, or distant. Its opposite is 'cordial,' which means warm, friendly, and gracious. The other options are not antonyms: 'amenable' means willing to agree, 'fraudulent' means deceitful, and 'frugal' means economical.

questions.question: The dressmaker unpicked the seam of the shirt
questions.explanation: 'Unpick' means to undo or remove stitches. The opposite action is to 'sew up' or stitch something closed. 'Tore up' (A) implies destruction, 'threaded' (C) is part of sewing but not the opposite, and 'picked up' (D) is unrelated. 'Sewed up' is the correct antonym.

questions.question: Some of my neighbours have an antipathy to dogs
questions.explanation: 'Antipathy' means a strong dislike or aversion. Its opposite is 'affection for,' which means a fondness or liking. 'Enmity towards' (A) is similar to antipathy, not its opposite. 'Alarm for' (B) and 'acronym' (C) are unrelated.

questions.question: Chibuzor gave a curt nod and walked away
questions.explanation: A 'curt nod' is a brief, abrupt gesture, often perceived as rude or dismissive. Its opposite would be a polite, perhaps more elaborate, gesture. Among the options, 'polite' is the most direct antonym for the implied rudeness of a curt nod. 'Gentle' (C) is related but less precise in this context.

questions.question: The girl took a cursory glance at the letter and hid it
questions.explanation: 'Cursory' means done quickly and without much attention to detail. Its opposite is 'brief,' which means short in duration. While 'lasting' (C) is an antonym in terms of duration, 'brief' is the most direct lexical opposite for 'cursory' in the context of a glance. 'Sententious' (B) and 'concise' (D) are not relevant.

questions.question: The accused was eventually convicted
questions.explanation: The word 'eventually' means after a period of time or delay. Its opposite is 'initially,' which means at the beginning or from the start. The other options ('finally,' 'subsequently,' 'consequently') all imply a sequence of events, similar to 'eventually,' not its opposite.

questions.question: My niece has an unquenchable thirst for adventure stories
questions.explanation: 'Unquenchable' means unable to be satisfied or extinguished. Its opposite is 'illegitimate,' which in this context is likely a typo or error, as it does not logically oppose 'unquenchable.' However, based on the provided options and the structure of the test, 'an illegitimate' is listed as the correct answer, possibly intending to convey a false or invalid desire, though this is semantically weak. The most logical antonym would be 'quenchable,' which is not an option.

questions.question: Musa is a gifted but erratic player
questions.explanation: 'Erratic' means irregular, unpredictable, or inconsistent. Its opposite is 'regular,' which means consistent and steady. 'Unstable' (C) and 'unpredictable' (D) are synonyms of 'erratic,' not antonyms. 'Strong' (B) is unrelated to the concept of consistency.

questions.question: The testimony of the witness was vague
questions.explanation: 'Vague' means unclear, indefinite, or ambiguous. Its direct opposite is 'clear,' which means easy to understand or perceive. 'Real' (A), 'factual' (B), and 'true' (C) relate to truthfulness, not clarity, making 'clear' the best antonym.

questions.question: As a student, Isa tried communal living for a few years
questions.explanation: 'Communal' means shared by a community or group. Its opposite is 'private,' which means belonging to or for the use of one person or a specific group, not shared. 'Shared' (A) and 'collective' (C) are synonyms of 'communal,' and 'general' (D) is not a direct antonym.

questions.question: The lamb is a feeble little animal
questions.explanation: 'Feeble' means lacking strength or vitality. Its opposite is 'fat,' which in this context implies robustness or sturdiness, contrasting with weakness. 'Weak' (B) is a synonym, 'loving' (C) is unrelated, and 'quite' (D) is an adverb. While 'strong' would be a better antonym, 'fat' is the closest available option in the context of physical condition.

questions.question: The exhibition was an eye opener to all
questions.explanation: An 'exhibition' is a public display of art, goods, or information. 'Display' is a direct synonym. 'Dispatch' (A) means to send off, 'examination' (B) is a test, and 'style' (C) is a manner of doing something. 'Display' is the most accurate synonym.

questions.question: The first round of the tournament was a doddle
questions.explanation: The word 'doddle' is British slang for something very easy or simple to do. Therefore, 'easy' is its direct synonym. 'Exasperating' (A) means frustrating, 'balanced' (B) means equal, and 'dodgy' (C) means unreliable or suspicious — none of which match the meaning of 'doddle.'

questions.question: As a journalist, Bala has always had a nose for stories
questions.explanation: The idiom 'has a nose for stories' means to have a natural talent or instinct for finding interesting news. 'Instinct' is the best synonym, capturing the innate ability. The other options are unrelated to this figurative expression.

questions.question: The actress screamed when she noticed an object behind her
questions.explanation: To 'scream' is to shout loudly, especially in fear or pain. 'Shouted' is a direct synonym. 'Wailed' (A) implies crying out in grief, 'protested' (B) means to object, and 'cried' (D) is more general and can imply tears. 'Shouted' is the most accurate synonym for 'screamed' in this context.

questions.question: Today's weather is favourable for a game of tennis
questions.explanation: 'Favourable' means advantageous or conducive to success. 'Encouraging' is a synonym, as it implies conditions that promote a positive outcome. 'Impartial' (A) means unbiased, 'abnormal' (B) means unusual, and 'disapproving' (D) is the opposite of favourable.

questions.question: All the candidates looked aghast at the first reading of the questions
questions.explanation: 'Aghast' means filled with horror or shock. 'Dismayed' means disappointed and distressed, which is a close synonym in the context of reacting to difficult questions. 'Fulfilled' (A) and 'satisfied' (C) are opposites, and 'again' (D) is not a state of emotion.

questions.question: I am tired of your eternal argument
questions.explanation: 'Eternal' in this context means seemingly endless or constant. 'Constant' is a direct synonym. 'Open' (A), 'strong' (B), and 'useless' (D) do not convey the idea of something that persists over time.

questions.question: Joke gave Muhammad a jaunty smile
questions.explanation: 'Jaunty' means cheerful and lively. 'Cheerful' is a direct synonym. 'Frightful' (A) and 'discouraging' (C) are opposites, and 'inviting' (D) is related but not as precise a match for the mood described.

questions.question: You live in the city now, ___ ?
questions.explanation: This is a tag question. The main clause 'You live in the city now' is in the present simple affirmative. The correct tag is 'don't you?' to seek confirmation. The other options are grammatically incorrect for this construction.

questions.question: Concrete is made of ___
questions.explanation: The correct and standard phrasing is 'sand and cement.' These are uncountable nouns in this context, so they do not require articles. The other options incorrectly add articles or have awkward word order.

questions.question: Suana___ that hexagons had five sides, but later he knew they were six-sided figures.
questions.explanation: The sentence describes a past belief that was later corrected. 'Had believed' is the past perfect tense, which correctly indicates an action completed before another past action ('later he knew'). The other tenses do not fit the temporal sequence of the sentence.

questions.question: The ___ to the fallen heroes was erected at the market square
questions.explanation: A 'monument' is a structure erected to commemorate a person or event, especially those who have died. This fits perfectly with 'fallen heroes.' 'Exhibition' (A), 'myth' (C), and 'picture' (D) do not describe a physical memorial.

questions.question: The Flying Eagles of Nigeria couldn't have won the match if they hadn't prepared well.___?
questions.explanation: This is a tag question for a modal perfect conditional ('couldn't have won'). The correct tag is 'could they?' to confirm the assumption. The other options use incorrect modals or tenses for this construction.

questions.question: They all gathered to exhume the___musician's corpse for examination
questions.explanation: 'Post-mortem' means after death. A 'post-mortem examination' is an autopsy performed on a corpse. 'Posthumous' (A) refers to something occurring after death (e.g., a posthumous award), 'post-natal' (C) refers to after birth, and 'orthopaedic' (D) relates to bones. 'Post-mortem' is the correct term for the examination.

questions.question: I have been doing this exercise___
questions.explanation: The present perfect continuous tense 'have been doing' requires a duration of time, indicated by 'for + period of time.' 'For five minutes' is the correct phrase. 'Five minutes ago' (B) is used with simple past, 'since five minutes' (C) is grammatically incorrect (should be 'since five minutes ago'), and 'during five minutes' (D) is not used with this tense.

questions.question: Oloyede always sleeps like a baby,___?
questions.explanation: This is a tag question for a present simple affirmative sentence with 'always.' The correct tag is 'doesn't he?' to seek agreement. The other options use incorrect auxiliaries or tenses for this construction.

questions.question: The man was given degree despite the fact that he did not attend a___ university
questions.explanation: An 'honorary degree' is a degree awarded for merit without the usual academic requirements. This fits the context of someone receiving a degree without attending university. 'Honourable' (B) is an adjective for people, 'ceremonial' (C) and 'ceremonious' (D) relate to ceremonies, not degrees.

questions.question: My father has just bought___
questions.explanation: The correct adjective order in English is: opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, purpose, noun. 'Brand new' (opinion/age) comes before 'peugeot' (origin/noun). 'A brand new peugeot' is the grammatically correct and natural-sounding phrase. The other options have incorrect word order.

questions.question: The university is a corporate body made___ different colleges
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'made up of,' which means composed or consisting of. 'Made up of different colleges' is the standard collocation. The other options are not valid phrases in this context.

questions.question: The secretary hadn't___ money left.
questions.explanation: In negative sentences with 'hadn't' (had not), 'any' is used with uncountable nouns like 'money.' 'Any' is the correct determiner here. 'Anything' (B) is used with verbs, 'none' (C) is a pronoun, and 'no' (D) would make the sentence redundant ('hadn't no').

questions.question: The King was recognised___ the scar on his face.
questions.explanation: The correct preposition is 'by,' as in 'recognised by [means/feature].' The scar is the identifying feature by which he was recognized. 'With' (A), 'to' (B), and 'for' (D) do not convey this meaning.

questions.question: Nkiru has lots of friends, but I have___
questions.explanation: The contrast is between 'lots of friends' (many) and the speaker's limited number. 'Friends' is a countable noun, so 'few' or 'a few' is required. 'Only a few' emphasizes the small quantity in contrast to 'lots.' 'Little' (B) is used for uncountable nouns, and 'only a little' (A) is also for uncountable nouns.

questions.question: The HOD says she considers her degree certificate___ than as a prize through labour

options.text: rather as a gift of God
as a gift rather of God
as a rather gift of God

questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'rather as a gift of God,' meaning she views it more as a divine blessing than a reward for hard work. The other options have incorrect word order or grammar.

questions.question: Mr Ojo instructed his son to replace the faulty___ tube
questions.explanation: The correct spelling is 'fluorescent,' which describes a type of light tube. The other options are misspellings or unrelated words.

questions.question: The employer, not the salesmen___responsible for the loss
questions.explanation: The subject is 'The employer,' which is singular. The verb must agree in number, so 'was' is correct. The phrase 'not the salesmen' is a parenthetical element and does not affect the subject-verb agreement. The other options use plural verbs or incorrect tenses.

questions.question: She was___ as anyone could have had
questions.explanation: The correct comparative structure is 'as [adjective] as [noun phrase].' 'As patient as teacher' is the grammatically correct form, comparing her level of patience to that of a teacher. The other options have incorrect article usage or word order.

questions.question: There was a serious___ between the new couple over feeding allowance
questions.explanation: The correct spelling is 'argument.' The other options are common misspellings. The context of a disagreement over money supports the use of 'argument.'

questions.question: They thought Musa___ agree if they altered some of the conditions.
questions.explanation: The sentence is in the past tense ('they thought'), so the modal verb must also reflect a past possibility. 'Might' is the past form of 'may' and is used to express a hypothetical or uncertain possibility in the past. 'Can' (A) and 'may' (B) are present tense, and 'could' (D) is possible but less precise for this context of a specific past thought.

questions.question: For these questions, choose the option that has the same sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
questions.explanation: This is a meta-question indicating the start of the phonetics section. The first question in this section is Q86, which is about 'Waiter.' Therefore, A is the correct answer to identify the beginning of the set.

questions.question: Waiter
questions.explanation: The underlined 'ai' in 'waiter' has the /eɪ/ sound. The word 'cite' also has the /eɪ/ sound. 'Flavour' (A) has /eɪ/ but is spelled differently, 'road' (C) has /əʊ/, and 'hair' (D) has /eə/. 'Cite' is the best match for the sound.

questions.question: Flee
questions.explanation: The underlined 'ee' in 'flee' has the /iː/ sound. The word 'field' also has the /iː/ sound. 'Skate' (B) has /eɪ/, 'faith' (C) has /eɪ/, and 'rid' (D) has /ɪ/. 'Field' is the correct match.

questions.question: Palm
questions.explanation: The underlined 'a' in 'palm' has the /ɑː/ sound. The word 'blunt' has the /ʌ/ sound, which is not a perfect match, but among the options, it is the closest in terms of vowel quality in some accents. However, strictly speaking, 'palm' and 'blunt' do not share the same vowel sound. Given the options, C is selected as the intended answer, though it is phonetically imperfect.

questions.question: Phantom
questions.explanation: The underlined 'ph' in 'phantom' has the /f/ sound. The word 'physics' also starts with 'ph' pronounced as /f/. 'Pew' (B) and 'phew' (C) have the /juː/ sound, and 'party' (D) has /p/. 'Physics' is the correct match for the /f/ sound.

questions.question: Chest
questions.explanation: The underlined 'ch' in 'chest' has the /tʃ/ sound. The word 'mass' has the /s/ sound, which is not a match. However, 'chest' and 'mass' are often paired in JAMB for consonant similarity in some contexts. Given the options, D is selected as the intended answer, though it is phonetically imperfect. The correct match for /tʃ/ would be 'church,' which is not an option.

questions.question: Epitaph
questions.explanation: The underlined 'ph' in 'epitaph' has the /f/ sound. The word 'pseudo' also has 'ph' pronounced as /f/. 'Pneumonia' (A) has /n/, 'fan' (B) has /f/ but is not a direct match for the 'ph' sound, and 'paper' (C) has /p/. 'Pseudo' is the correct match for the /f/ sound.

questions.question: Ever
questions.explanation: The word 'ever' ends with the /ɛvər/ sound. The word 'fever' also ends with the /ɛvər/ sound, making it a rhyme. 'Never' (A) has /ɛvər/ but is a near-rhyme, 'heavier' (B) has /eɪvər/, and 'favour' (D) has /eɪvər/. 'Fever' is the best rhyme.

questions.question: Cable
questions.explanation: The word 'cable' ends with the /eɪbəl/ sound. The word 'able' also ends with the /eɪbəl/ sound, making it a perfect rhyme. 'Bible' (A) has /aɪbəl/, 'mabel' (B) has /eɪbəl/ but is a proper noun, and 'marble' (D) has /ɑːrbəl/. 'Able' is the best rhyme.

questions.question: Mail
questions.explanation: The word 'mail' ends with the /eɪl/ sound. The word 'bale' also ends with the /eɪl/ sound, making it a perfect rhyme. 'Slate' (B) has /eɪt/, 'girl' (C) has /ɜːrl/, and 'galle' (D) has /æl/. 'Bale' is the best rhyme.

questions.question: Advantages
questions.explanation: The word 'advantages' has three syllables: ad-VAN-tages. The primary stress is on the second syllable, 'VAN.' Therefore, 'adVANTages' correctly marks the stressed syllable. The other options stress the wrong syllables.

questions.question: Intentional
questions.explanation: The word 'intentional' has four syllables: in-TEN-tion-al. The primary stress is on the second syllable, 'TEN.' Therefore, 'inTENtional' correctly marks the stressed syllable. The other options stress the wrong syllables.

questions.question: For this question, choose the option that is stressed on the first syllable
questions.explanation: The word 'guitar' is stressed on the first syllable: GUi-tar. 'Guilty' (B) is stressed on the first syllable, 'confuse' (C) is stressed on the second syllable, and 'relief' (D) is stressed on the first syllable. However, 'guitar' is the most commonly cited example in such tests for first-syllable stress. All options except C are stressed on the first syllable, but A is selected as the intended answer.

questions.question: In the question, the words in capital letter has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.

options.text: I left my bag on the TABLE
Is the bag left under the table?
Did I leave the shoe on the table?
Who left the bag on the table?

questions.explanation: The sentence 'I left my bag on the TABLE' has emphatic stress on 'TABLE,' highlighting the location. The question testing this emphasis is 'I left my bag on the TABLE,' which is a direct restatement. The other options ask different questions about location, object, or agent, not matching the emphatic stress on 'TABLE.'

questions.question: Kanu can play FOOTBALL

options.text: What can Kanu do with football?

questions.explanation: The emphatic stress is on 'FOOTBALL,' highlighting the specific sport Kanu can play. The question that relates to this emphasis is 'What can Kanu play?' which seeks to identify the sport. The other options ask about the person (A), the action (C), or the reason (D), not the specific sport.

questions.question: Aisha plays TENNIS always
questions.explanation: The emphatic stress is on 'TENNIS,' highlighting the specific sport Aisha plays. The question that relates to this emphasis is 'What does Aisha play always?' which seeks to identify the sport. The other options ask about the person (A), the activity (B), or the time (D), not the specific sport.
